section.title: Problem
section.para: You want to write a customization layer for the DocBook XSL stylesheets, but you do not know how to do it.

section.title: Solution
section.para: A DocBook XSL customization layer comprises the following components:

listitem.para: An XSLT stylesheet skeleton with the start tag xsl:stylesheet and the end tag xsl:stylesheet
At least the namespaces for XSLT, DocBook 5, and your output format (for example, FO or XHTML).
An xsl:import element to incoporate the base DocBook XSLT stylesheet.
Your customizations (parameters, variables, templates, or other imports).

section.para: How this can look is shown in the following listing.

example.title: General Customization Layer
example.programlisting:
<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" xmlns:d="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook">
<xsl:import href="https://cdn.docbook.org/release/xsl/current/FORMAT/docbook.xsl"/>
<!-- Your customizations go here -->
</xsl:stylesheet>

section.title: Discussion
section.para: Why not modify the original stylesheets? There are some profound reasons which speak against such modifications:

listitem.para: Whenever you update your stylesheet, all your modifications are lost.
You cannot separate between different customizations, for example, in one book you need an index but in the other it is unwanted.
If you modify the original stylesheets directly you cannot go back to the former output.
It is hard to distinguish between your customizations and the original one.

section.para: Refrain from editing the original stylesheets! Always write a customization layer.
Apart from the obvious reasons above, the following list gives you some recommendations:

listitem.para: Insert common parameters or templates into a stylesheet which is included in your customizations.
Structure your output formats into separate directories as shown in .
Name your main stylesheet docbook.xsl or chunk.xsl (HTML only).
If your customization grows, outsource your customization into several stylesheets and include them into your main stylesheet.
Name your files like the DocBook XSL stylesheets. For example, if you customize filename (an inline element) put it into the file inline.xsl.

section.para: An example how this can look like, is shown in :

example.title: Structure
example.screen: mycustomizations/ +-- common/ +-- common.xsl +-- fo/ +-- docbook.xsl +-- inline.xsl +-- html/ +-- docbook.xsl +-- chunk.xsl +-- inline.xsl

callout.para: Main stylesheet for FO output; includes inline.xsl
Contains all modifications for inline elements regarding the FO output.
Main stylesheet for single HTML output; includes inline.xsl
Main stylesheet for chunked HTML output; imports docbook.xsl
Contains all modifications for inline elements regarding the HTML output.
